page.title: 07WORKING MEN'S CLUB, WALL
page.content: The Working Men's Club or Village Hall, as it is now more often called, in Wall was built in 1908. It was given to the men by a local benefactor. The annual rent paid was two guineas and conditions included "No alcohol" and "No politics". If the Club was not used it was to be turned into cottages. The hall was used for war effort, sewing etc. and by the Women's Institute from 1912. It is used regularly today - snooker and darts for men, handicraft classes for women and weekly Whist Drives. Wedding receptions, parties and dances are also held in the hall and the W.I. use it for their monthly meetings. After much fund-raising by the villagers a large kitchen extension was built in 1984 which greatly improved the facilities. The original conditions relating to alcohol and politics no longer apply.
